content: My daughter is in the army,, In Iraq right now. Actually Hunter. (wherever that is) I have her two year old while shes gone. We like to send packages for her, and her platoon, as they arent in a good place right now and really enjoy the treats and snacks and such. As well as pictures of the baby. Anyway. She finally got to call me the other day and said that nobody has recieved a package for almost two months.?? I mailed one 6 weeks ago and one again a couple of weeks ago. They havent recieved anything. All their mail and packages are being held back at a base somewhere. And not planning on delivering them any time soon either from what shes heard. Is this normal.. I can not believe they are out there,,In the sand and heat, Little comforts, being shot at daily from what little she can tell me,, and their not getting any mail. No correspondence going out either. I realize we are at war, and its not easy,, but, Is this the norm?? Who can I write to or complain to.. Those soilders NEED those packages and support and letters and cards and pictures from home!!! I am so upset!! I dont know what I can do.. Can I do anything??
reply: My daughter is in the army,, In Iraq right now. Actually Hunter. (wherever that is) I have her two year old while shes gone. They havent recieved anything. All their mail and packages are being held back at a base somewhere. And not planning on delivering them any time soon either from what shes heard. Is this normal.. I can not believe they are out there,,In the sand and heat, Little comforts, being shot at daily from what little she can tell me,, and their not getting any mail. No correspondence going out either. I realize we are at war, and its not easy,, but, Is this the norm?? Who can I write to or complain to.. Those soilders NEED those packages and support and letters and cards and pictures from home!!! I am so upset!! I dont know what I can do.. Can I do anything??
title: Is this Normal?

content: Its probbly not unusual. During desert sheild/storm , mail came interminably. Mail does not get high priority. when going over seas. Just depends on what space is available on planes. Is this legal? I don't know,but its fun isn't?!
reply: Its probbly not unusual. During desert sheild/storm , mail came interminably. Mail does not get high priority. when going over seas. Just depends on what space is available on planes. Is this legal? I don't know,but its fun isn't?!
title: Is this Normal?

content: I wouldn't doubt it. Just as DsTremf said. I was in Desert Storm also. We'ld hear through the grapevine how all these corporations donated TV's, VCR's, etc. All the good stuff. None of it ever made it our way. I assumed some SOB General, or his HQ's got the good stuff. It may sound bad, but that is why I do not send anything to the any soldier address. Probably some jerk in a mailroom somewhere over there taking them all, and doing some black marketeering. Your complaint is legitimate, and I would pass your question onto your congressman. Sometimes it takes a congressional inquiry for things to straiten up. The local news here in Dallas would love I am sure, to do a story about troops NOT getting their mail. Good Luck, in whatever you choose to do.
reply: I wouldn't doubt it. Just as DsTremf said. I was in Desert Storm also. We'ld hear through the grapevine how all these corporations donated TV's, VCR's, etc. All the good stuff. Good Luck, in whatever you choose to do.

I am so upset!! I dont know what I can do.. Can I do anything?? Unfortunately, mail going into Third World countries and drifting through the military mail system are often subject to pilfering and black market activities. Many GIs are receiving high quality stuff - everything from food to socks to better sights from Cabela's for their M-16s - from caring relatives who want them to have a little joy, or the best equipment hard earned cash can buy... And the crooks know it... So stuff disappears. But it also gets blown up, burned, destroyed when convoys get hit... More often than not, it gets delayed in huge pile-ups on docks or in warehouses because of inefficient shipping choices, and being lower on the priority list than beans and bullets... Patience is golden, they say - - Might post on the ARMY forum for closer contact and help - - http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/frm/f/65819558 Wandering and Wondering

reply: Unfortunately, mail going into Third World countries and drifting through the military mail system are often subject to pilfering and black market activities. Many GIs are receiving high quality stuff - everything from food to socks to better sights from Cabela's for their M-16s - from caring relatives who want them to have a little joy, or the best equipment hard earned cash can buy... And the crooks know it... So stuff disappears. But it also gets blown up, burned, destroyed when convoys get hit... More often than not, it gets delayed in huge pile-ups on docks or in warehouses because of inefficient shipping choices, and being lower on the priority list than beans and bullets... Patience is golden, they say - - Might post on the ARMY forum for closer contact and help - - http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/frm/f/65819558 Wandering and Wondering
title: Is this Normal?

content: I remember being on patrol with the USCG in the Caribbean and having our mail dropped to us in a plastic cylinder from a low and slow flying USCG Falcon jet. That seemed a bit bizarre. Just a photo I found on the internet. With us, they just dropped it into the ocean without any parachute for us to retrieve....and yes, it did stay dry. Don
reply: I remember being on patrol with the USCG in the Caribbean and having our mail dropped to us in a plastic cylinder from a low and slow flying USCG Falcon jet. That seemed a bit bizarre. title: Is this Normal?

content: There's still IEDs and mortars. People are still getting killed over there. It's just that violence has dropped enough there, and gone up enough in Afghanistan that Iraq is now the safer locale. Go figure. Mail issues are common. ESPECIALLY if she is at a remote base. If you are on a main base, and everything is in place, you will get most mail within 14 days. Amazon.com can get stuff to Kirkuk, Iraq inside of seven days, though nine is the norm. Remote bases have issues, they only get mail when they get convoys, and when convoy space is available. Also, to be honest, there are some packages that just disappear. Not sure where they end up... If you're going to send expensive or good things, spread them out over several packages, and accept the fact that it's possible a couple of them won't ever get through. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Ruanne, Mon 09 March 2009 09:24 PM
reply: There's still IEDs and mortars. People are still getting killed over there. It's just that violence has dropped enough there, and gone up enough in Afghanistan that Iraq is now the safer locale. Go figure. Mail issues are common. ESPECIALLY if she is at a remote base. If you are on a main base, and everything is in place, you will get most mail within 14 days. Amazon.com can get stuff to Kirkuk, Iraq inside of seven days, though nine is the norm. Remote bases have issues, they only get mail when they get convoys, and when convoy space is available. Also, to be honest, there are some packages that just disappear. Not sure where they end up... If you're going to send expensive or good things, spread them out over several packages, and accept the fact that it's possible a couple of them won't ever get through. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Ruanne, Mon 09 March 2009 09:24 PM

content: notthing to do with iraq mail but i remember sitting in the plane on my way to costa rica on a surf trip and i see my SOFT boardbag with 6 boards in it get 3/4 up the belt to the cargo bay of the aircraft and wouldnt you know it? NOSEDIVE off that mother..i just remember saying.. oh thats just friggin lovely. thank you newark international baggage crew..

content: My daughter is in the army,, In Iraq right now. Actually Hunter. (wherever that is) I have her two year old while shes gone. We like to send packages for her, and her platoon, as they arent in a good place right now and really enjoy the treats and snacks and such. As well as pictures of the baby. Anyway. She finally got to call me the other day and said that nobody has recieved a package for almost two months.?? I mailed one 6 weeks ago and one again a couple of weeks ago. They havent recieved anything. All their mail and packages are being held back at a base somewhere. And not planning on delivering them any time soon either from what shes heard. Is this normal.. I can not believe they are out there,,In the sand and heat, Little comforts, being shot at daily from what little she can tell me,, and their not getting any mail. No correspondence going out either. I realize we are at war, and its not easy,, but, Is this the norm?? Who can I write to or complain to.. Those soilders NEED those packages and support and letters and cards and pictures from home!!! I am so upset!! I dont know what I can do.. Can I do anything??

title: Is this Normal?

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: I remember being on patrol with the USCG in the Caribbean and having our mail dropped to us in a plastic cylinder from a low and slow flying USCG Falcon jet. That seemed a bit bizarre. Just a photo I found on the internet. With us, they just dropped it into the ocean without any parachute for us to retrieve....and yes, it did stay dry. Don HEY! I worked with jets just like that during drug interdiction missions in the Caribbean during the 80s (Note FLIR pod under nose). They were cool folk to work with!! Wandering and Wondering

content: ----- I was in Nam , 1969 -- 5 months after Nam, I was still getting mail from Nam to Ft. Carson, Co.! That was when we had 1/2 million boots getting mail. It`s sure to catch up. -- Not to worry.

title: Is this Normal?

content: There's still IEDs and mortars. People are still getting killed over there. It's just that violence has dropped enough there, and gone up enough in Afghanistan that Iraq is now the safer locale. Go figure. Mail issues are common. ESPECIALLY if she is at a remote base. If you are on a main base, and everything is in place, you will get most mail within 14 days. Amazon.com can get stuff to Kirkuk, Iraq inside of seven days, though nine is the norm. Remote bases have issues, they only get mail when they get convoys, and when convoy space is available. Also, to be honest, there are some packages that just disappear. Not sure where they end up... If you're going to send expensive or good things, spread them out over several packages, and accept the fact that it's possible a couple of them won't ever get through. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Ruanne, Mon 09 March 2009 09:24 PM
reply: There's still IEDs and mortars. People are still getting killed over there. It's just that violence has dropped enough there, and gone up enough in Afghanistan that Iraq is now the safer locale. Go figure. Mail issues are common. ESPECIALLY if she is at a remote base. If you are on a main base, and everything is in place, you will get most mail within 14 days. Amazon.com can get stuff to Kirkuk, Iraq inside of seven days, though nine is the norm. Remote bases have issues, they only get mail when they get convoys, and when convoy space is available. Also, to be honest, there are some packages that just disappear. Not sure where they end up... If you're going to send expensive or good things, spread them out over several packages, and accept the fact that it's possible a couple of them won't ever get through. This message has been edited. content: notthing to do with iraq mail but i remember sitting in the plane on my way to costa rica on a surf trip and i see my SOFT boardbag with 6 boards in it get 3/4 up the belt to the cargo bay of the aircraft and wouldnt you know it? NOSEDIVE off that mother..i just remember saying.. oh thats just friggin lovely. thank you newark international baggage crew..
